docs.lead_paragraph: IRRADIATION has become a way of life in the United States. Though not well known, irradiation, or the use of small, tightly controlled doses of nuclear energy to kill harmful bacteria, is an increasingly common way to sterilize medical products. In addition, roughly 30 percent of the spices used here are irradiated, as are a growing number of cosmetics. Containers of all kinds, including many of the tiny plastic cups used for milk at coffee shops, are irradiated. Various fruits and vegetables, and poultry, are often irradiated, too.

headline.main: Red Meat May Not Be Enough for Irradiation Companies

docs.abstract: Analysts who follow companies involved in irradiation of food are skeptical at best their prospects about Food and Drug Administration's decision to allow irradiation of red meats; cite doubts about consumer reactions and cost of building new facilities; most analysts believe some irrradiation will take place, but there remain big issues about how much and how fast (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Board of Legislators has begun leaving its mark on Westchester's proposed 1998 county budget, adding about $6 million in net spending to the original $1.025 billion budget proposed by departing County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. Faced with a Dec. 1 deadline after which additions could no longer be made, the Board's Committee on Budget and Appropriations tentatively added about $27 million in gross spending. But much of this would be offset by additional revenues or reductions in some associated programs.

headline.main: Board Adds Spending To O'Rourke Budget

docs.abstract: Board of Legislators adds about $6 million in net spending to Westchester's proposed 1998 county budget proposed by departing County Executive Andrew P O'Rourke; tentative additions made by Budget Committee outlined; as proposed by O'Rourke, budget will raise county's property tax 8 percent (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HILLARY was right about health care. Well, not quite: Hardly anybody expects Congress to micro-manage medical services or to cap the maximum amount Americans are permitted to spend on insurance. But confidence that the health care system can solve its problems without a lot of help from Washington is rapidly evaporating. As recently as a year or two ago, care regulated solely by the free market seemed the wave of the future, with feisty, profit-driven health maintenance organizations in the vanguard of the struggle to stamp out waste and remove medical specialists from the gravy train. Today, those H.M.O.'s are reporting falling earnings as they struggle with both angry consumers demanding better service and a medical establishment determined to resist any more cutbacks in fees.

headline.main: Backlash; In Medicine, Government Rises Again

docs.abstract: Peter Passell article contends that confidence that health care system can solve its problems without lot of help from Washington is rapidly evaporating; says as recently as year ago, care regulated solely by free market seemed wave of future, with profit-driven health mantenance organizations in vanguard of struggle to stamp out waste; says today HMOs are reporting falling earnings as they struggle with angry consumers demanding better service and medical establishment determined to resist any more cutbacks in fees; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the final day to apply for a clerical position with the New York City government, and people were making hurried pilgrimages to the city's personnel office in lower Manhattan, a procession of the chronically unemployed and the recently laid off, part-time workers clasping wrinkled resumes and welfare recipients towing young children. Many of them were optimistic on that day late last month, but that may have been because they did not know their chances. Officials estimated that nearly 35,000 people were seeking clerical jobs, whose starting salary is about $18,000 a year. If recent history is any guide, only a few hundred will get those jobs any time soon, no matter how qualified they are.

headline.main: A Scaled-Down City Government Has Fewer Jobs for the Hopeful

docs.abstract: Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani's effort to scale down New York City Government has led to a stark retrenchment in city hiring, putting an end to the city's traditional role as a jobs engine for the masses; but even after the city shed thousands of jobs and the municipal work force ceased to be a bastion of secure employment, people still clamor to get in--just as they have for most of this century; photos of job seekers in 1939 and today (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Losing a job is never fun. Some dismissals are handled with tact; others with a heavy hand. Sometimes, in retrospect, there is cause for laughter. Sometimes the sting lingers. And sometimes losing a job can be a healthy lesson in life. Gary Haynes has heard about the oblique approach to dismissals. He was working for The Philadelphia Inquirer in the late 1970's and recalls an executive at the newspaper's parent company, Knight-Ridder in Miami, who had a reputation for fatal Friday lunches.

headline.main: When Parting Is Such Strange Sorrow

docs.abstract: On the Job: readers describe how they were dismissed from their jobs; some were handled with tact, others with heavy hand; sometimes, in retrospect, there was cause for laughter; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN New Yorkers talk about their ''neighborhood,'' they most likely mean the streets filled with the places they patronize -- to buy vegetables, drop off dry cleaning, rent a video, fill a prescription or eat Chinese food. Small businesses, and the familiar faces running them, are a big part of an urbanite's daily life -- and vital to the nation's economic health. Then there is that other New York ''neighborhood,'' the skyscraper-and-cyberspace precincts that house the city's financial powerhouses. Here, the ZIP code may be local, but the customers and power are global.

headline.main: Making It in Manhattan: A Tale of Two Cities

docs.abstract: Deborah Stead review describes Tom Shachtman's book, Around the Block: The Business of a Neighborhood, as lively, insightful chronicle of year in business life of Manhattan block; block has 100 small enterprises, more than some midsized towns, with mix typical of middle-class Manhattan street; Stead says Frank Partnoy's book, F.I.A.S.C.O.: Blood in the Water on Wall Street, is fascinating look at derivatives; Partnoy claims Wall Street is making huge amount of money on derivatives by trickery or deceit (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite Governor Whitman's near-defeat last month, New Jersey's Democrats did not make any significant gains in the General Assembly or the Senate. Republicans remain firmly in control of the Legislature. Democrats can accomplish, little, if anything, on their own. So what role will Democrats now play in Trenton? Will they continue in their role as naysayers or join forces with their Republican colleagues so that lawmakers, and not Mrs. Whitman, wield the most influence over state policy and politics in the coming four years?

headline.main: A New Democratic Leader Sees Bipartisanship

docs.abstract: Jennifer Preston column profiles New Jersey Senate minority leader, Richard J Codey, who says he will seek more cooperative relationship with Republican leaders (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE quiet, orderly office of the Department of Social Services in Norwich bears no resemblance to the chaos in the lives of the people who pass through the door seeking help. Norwich, a flourishing city of textile mills at the turn of the century, joined the rest of New England in losing its manufacturing base in the post-World War II period. The city was hit hard again in the late 1980's, when the state's military industries began laying off workers and its unemployment rate remains consistently higher than elsewhere in the state.

headline.main: State or Towns: Who's Better at Caring for the Poor?

docs.abstract: Article focuses on outlook for many Connecticut localities as State Department of Social Services prepares to take control of all general assistance programs by July of 1998; state will handle only mandated benefits at its 14 regional offices, while cities and towns are expected to continue providing services like home visits and crisis management; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TAX reform may prove to be for Republicans what health care reform was for Democrats -- a seemingly popular idea that turned into a political disaster. In the case of health care, a 1991 Gallup Poll showed that 85 percent of Americans believed that the system needed reforming. Bill Clinton seized on this mood and made health care reform a centerpiece of his 1992 election campaign. Good medical insurance, he declared, was a right, not a privilege. He promised to make it affordable to everyone.

headline.main: Health-Care Reform Redux; A Tax Overhaul Looks Good, From Afar

docs.abstract: David E Rosenbaum article contends that tax reform may prove to be for Republicans what health care reform was for Democrats--seemingly popular idea that turned into political disaster; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Small Rooms for Boys and Girls MONDAY -- The Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club will benefit from an auction at Christie's of miniature rooms created by more than 15 interior designers. A cocktail reception at 6 P.M. will be followed by the auction, conducted by Christopher Burge, the chairman of Christie's in the United States. The evening will conclude with dinner at Doubles, in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel. Tickets, $130; $60 for the auction only, or $70 for dinner alone, from (718) 893-8600, ext. 236. Helping City Scholars MONDAY -- A black-tie dinner and dance at the Waldorf-Astoria will raise money for the Inner-City Scholarship Fund of the Archdiocese of New York. The event will begin with a reception at 6:30. Tickets, $750, from (212) 753-8583.
